issue.title: Get js stack in hermes engine

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

comment.body:
> There's a couple possible reasons you could be getting empty string back from this function.
> 
> 1. You're calling into the Runtime when there are no call frames, i.e. from the event loop when no JS is executing. You'd have to ensure that you're looking for the callstack while the JS has frames currently running.
> 2. It's very unlikely, but maybe the `HermesRuntime` you're calling the function on is not pointing to a valid `HermesRuntime`.

I think there is no problem with the HermesRuntime pointing, because I have tried to synchronously call the Native method from RN through JSI. At this time, calling getCallStackNoAlloc can get the stack.

Most likely it is due to the event loop when no JS is executing, but I have also tried calling it while monitor JSThread's RunLoop and calling it after suspending JSThread. Anyway, as long as it is actively obtained by Native, the JS call stack cannot be obtained through this API.

issue.title: Support for ES2018 Unicode character class escapes

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: es2018
labels.description: es2018+ compatibility

issue.body:
## Bug Description

`new RegExp(/\p{P}/, 'u')` in JS code crashes React Native when using Hermes, throwing `SyntaxError: Invalid RegExp: Invalid escape`; and it works fine with JSC. `\p{P}` is the [Unicode character class escape](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Regular_expressions/Unicode_character_class_escape) for punctuation.

- [x] I have run `gradle clean` and confirmed this bug does not occur with JSC

Hermes version: the one bundled with RN 0.71.10
React Native version (if any): 0.71.10
OS version (if any):
Platform (most likely one of arm64-v8a, armeabi-v7a, x86, x86_64):

comment.body: Thanks @tmikov! I'll start looking around the Hermes repo to find out if I can do it. Will post any doubts here if that works out

issue.title: Get js stack in hermes engine

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

comment.body:
There's a couple possible reasons you could be getting empty string back from this function.

1. You're calling into the Runtime when there are no call frames, i.e. from the event loop when no JS is executing. You'd have to ensure that you're looking for the callstack while the JS has frames currently running.
2. It's very unlikely, but maybe the `HermesRuntime` you're calling the function on is not pointing to a valid `HermesRuntime`.

comment.body:
@mandrade2 It's difficult to gauge exactly how friendly it is. It requires good C++, understanding of Unicode, regular expressions in general, and the Hermes regex implementation. It is not strongly coupled to the rest of the runtime, but likely requires calling internal APIs in ways that they are already used in the internal implementation.

I would say that this is a moderately complex task that would require non-trivial time commitment.

issue.title: Optimize Equality Operations Indifferent To Null & Undefined

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: Do not delete this pull request or issue due to inactivity.

issue.body:
## Summary

`null` and `undefined` are two of the most common JavaScript literals, and yet for the `==` and `!=` operations, they can be treated interchangeably. As they are semantically equivalent, it's really a stylistic preference which one is used. That said `!= null` and `!= undefined` are hugely common comparisons, not only in user code but with powering `??` and `?.` transforms.

Recognizing this indifference offers at least 2 optimization opportunities:

* Normalize operand literals to provide more opportunities for subsequent optimization passes, like CSE.
* Reduce the number of load constant statements required in byte-code (smaller bundle, fewer register allocations).

The first opportunity is realized in `lib/Optimizer/Scalar/InstSimplify.cpp`, by rewriting any `null` literals in `==` or `!=` operators with `undefined`. Whilst we could have opted to instead rewrite `undefined` to `null`, empirically `undefined` yielded better optimized output as `undefined` is more commonly used in other boiler-plate byte-code (for example, when calling functions).

The second opportunity is realized in the `LoadConstants::runOnFunction` pass in `lib/BCGen/HBC/Passes.cpp`, by replacing `null` or `undefined` literal operands in indifferent`BinaryOperatorInstr` with nearby operand literals from instructions that *do* discriminate.

Why both in one PR? As shown in the test plan, each of these optimizations yield similar efficiencies but together perform optimally as the second avoids regressions in the first where a `null` suffices in a function without an `undefined`; and the first happens earlier on in the optimization pipeline and so allows other optimizations to kick-in that the second-alone can't achieve.

_Note: I did consider pulling the second opportunity into a separate pass outside of `LoadConstants::runOnFunction` but on-balance it felt like performing an additional full pass would be expensive, and I hope that the code isn't too invasive._

### Clean-Up:

* In `lib/IR/Instrs.cpp`, I introduced a new `BinaryOperatorInst::looseToStrictEqualityOperator(...)` helper method which converts `==` to `===` and `!=` to `!==`.
* In `lib/Optimizer/Scalar/InstSimplify.cpp`, I collapse the `==` and `!=` switch cases  as the code was already near identical and introducing this optimization block to both cases was further adding to the duplication.
* In `lib/BCGen/HBC/Passes.cpp`, I refactor the unique literal memoization code into a `getLoadEntry` lambda function so it can be re-used outside of the for-loop in the clean-up assignment pass.

## Test Plan
We execute `../build/bin/hermes -dump-bytecode -O ../bk.js` against a 33MB React Native production bundle.

```
wc -l ../byte*
 2871165 ../bytecode.bk.none.out
 2867422 ../bytecode.bk.first.out (saved 3,743 statements)
 2867409 ../bytecode.bk.second.out (saved 3,756 statements)
 2867329 ../bytecode.bk.both.out (saved 3,836 statements)
```

We also add tests for the specific use-cases that are being optimized:

```
$ cmake --build ../build --target check-hermes all -j 4
[0/1] Running the Hermes regression tests
Testing Time: 19.79s
  Expected Passes    : 1681
  Unsupported Tests  : 6
```

comment.body:
Hi, sorry we haven't commented here in a while,I haven't forgotten about these PRs, though admittedly https://github.com/facebook/hermes/pull/1175 made me feel more guilty.

Since we have now publicly announced Static Hermes, I can finally be fully transparent. When we started working on Static Hermes, which will be a drop-in replacement for Hermes, among many other things, Hermes has been frozen except for bugfixes and small changes that can trivially be ported to the Static Hermes branch without rebase conflicts. 

Accepting a change this in Hermes would create **a lot** of work for us porting to Static Hermes, where the compiler has diverged, especially given that Hermes is frozen.

I realize that this is creating even more churn for you, bit this and https://github.com/facebook/hermes/pull/1075 should really be against the `static_h` branch. Then we will integrate it, and it will be maintained, etc.

issue.body:
## Bug Description

`new RegExp(/\p{P}/, 'u')` in JS code crashes React Native when using Hermes, throwing `SyntaxError: Invalid RegExp: Invalid escape`; and it works fine with JSC. `\p{P}` is the [Unicode character class escape](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Regular_expressions/Unicode_character_class_escape) for punctuation.

- [x] I have run `gradle clean` and confirmed this bug does not occur with JSC

Hermes version: the one bundled with RN 0.71.10
React Native version (if any): 0.71.10
OS version (if any):
Platform (most likely one of arm64-v8a, armeabi-v7a, x86, x86_64):

comment.body: Is this new-contributor friendly? I'd be happy to implement it. Need it in my app

In general, we avoid having any global constructors. Keeping this as a static local or a global may also not be thread safe, as multiple runtimes can exist in the same process running on different threads. (`std::uniform_real_distribution<RealType>::operator()` is not const)

We can just keep this as a local to avoid these issues and minimise the scope of this change.

issue.title: Get js stack in hermes engine

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

commits.message:
Maintain ordering of loaded scripts take 2

Summary:
Same change as D50236422, which had to be reverted due to it causing a
crash. This new diff fixes a previously unknown bug where CDPHandler
doesn't handle invalid SourceLocation properly.

We used to keep track of the loaded scripts in an `unordered_map`. This
means that when a client connects and sends us a Debugger.enable
message, the scriptParsed notifications that we send are not the same
order as when those loaded scripts appeared.

This is a problem because DevTools'
[DebuggerModel.ts](https://github.com/ChromeDevTools/devtools-frontend/blob/main/front_end/core/sdk/DebuggerModel.ts#L756) treats the
scriptParsed that appear later on as the newest version of the script.

For the React Native Fast Refresh scenario where the same script gets
modified and loaded multiple times, we want DevTools to treat the last
loaded version as the newest version.

Fixing this issue by switching to use a vector so that the behavior is
more like we buffered the loaded scripts and then send the scriptParsed
notifications in the order that they would have been sent if the
debugger client was already connected.

Reviewed By: fbmal7

Differential Revision: D50514612

fbshipit-source-id: 713ee7f9b1f484723419b9701877910bf513622e

Use -Wx for exec arguments in shermes

Summary:
The positional arguments will now be used for multiple file inputs,
instead of for exec args.
Exec args can still be passed via the `-Wx,` argument much like compiler
args.

Reviewed By: neildhar

Differential Revision: D50674605

fbshipit-source-id: 2a02a09fec000e614367c5d032ae910107d9b084

Concat multiple CLI scripts in shermes.cpp

Summary:
The resulting files are parsed, and their ASTs are concatenated
before being wrapped in the IIFE.

Reviewed By: neildhar

Differential Revision: D50674387

fbshipit-source-id: 1e7d311b6e713910066ac11e695b5af44661deb9

Fix hdb hermesvm link

Summary: Wrong library was being linked.

Reviewed By: neildhar

Differential Revision: D50673547

fbshipit-source-id: 85d63a2f4d531a7b853ffe2f09bd94ec461c2712

Include Hermes JSI implementation in libhermesvm

Summary:
Make the Hermes API implementation a part of `libhermesvm`, so that it
exposes both the SH functions and JSI.

Delete libhermes, since it depends on `hermesvm`, which now already
contains the files used by libhermes.

Reviewed By: tmikov

Differential Revision: D50650685

fbshipit-source-id: 066c34d2ce7c5ffbb9b95e5ecec60f1acb16b779

Always create SHRuntime through JSI runtime

Summary:
Instead of operating on `vm::Runtime`, operate on `HermesRuntime`. This
ensures that we can use JSI with SH code.

Reviewed By: tmikov

Differential Revision: D50650686

fbshipit-source-id: 8417fb0a8705805e76b4e27c83e9f920386b04b1

Patch prettier#15514 into prettier version

Summary:
Sync the latest version of https://github.com/pieterv/prettier/commits/hermes-v2-backport

- This includes prettier#15514 (https://github.com/prettier/prettier/pull/15514)

Reviewed By: jbrown215

Differential Revision: D50662620
